DataElement.preferredName: WHO Classification of Tumors Ovarian Histologic Grade
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The histological classification of ovarian tumors by the World Health Organization (WHO).

DataElementConcept.preferredName: WHO Classification of Tumors Ovarian Histologic Grade
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A classification of benign and malignant tumors by World Health Organization (WHO) experts based primarily on histologic findings._Having to do with the ovaries, the female reproductive glands in which the ova (eggs) are formed. The ovaries are located in the pelvis, one on each side of the uterus._The degree of abnormality of cancer cells, a measure of differentiation, the extent to which cancer cells are similar in appearance and function to healthy cells of the same tissue type. The degree of differentiation often relates to the clinical behavior of the particular tumor. Based on the microscopic findings, tumor grade is commonly described by one of four degrees of severity. Histopathologic grade of a tumor may be used to plan treatment and estimate the future course, outcome, and overall prognosis of disease. Certain types of cancers, such as soft tissue sarcoma, primary brain tumors, lymphomas, and breast have special grading systems.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A classification of benign and malignant tumors by World Health Organization (WHO) experts based primarily on histologic findings.

Concepts.definition: A classification of benign and malignant tumors by World Health Organization (WHO) experts based primarily on histologic findings.

Property.preferredDefinition: Having to do with the ovaries, the female reproductive glands in which the ova (eggs) are formed. The ovaries are located in the pelvis, one on each side of the uterus.:The degree of abnormality of cancer cells, a measure of differentiation, the extent to which cancer cells are similar in appearance and function to healthy cells of the same tissue type. The degree of differentiation often relates to the clinical behavior of the particular tumor. Based on the microscopic findings, tumor grade is commonly described by one of four degrees of severity. Histopathologic grade of a tumor may be used to plan treatment and estimate the future course, outcome, and overall prognosis of disease. Concepts.definition: Having to do with the ovaries, the female reproductive glands in which the ova (eggs) are formed. The ovaries are located in the pelvis, one on each side of the uterus.

The degree of abnormality of cancer cells, a measure of differentiation, the extent to which cancer cells are similar in appearance and function to healthy cells of the same tissue type. The degree of differentiation often relates to the clinical behavior of the particular tumor. Based on the microscopic findings, tumor grade is commonly described by one of four degrees of severity. Histopathologic grade of a tumor may be used to plan treatment and estimate the future course, outcome, and overall prognosis of disease. Certain types of cancers, such as soft tissue sarcoma, primary brain tumors, lymphomas, and breast have special grading systems.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Specification of human conditions relevant to cancer. This includes observations, test results, history, and other concepts relevant to characterization of human cancer-related conditions. Non-neoplastic conditions of interest are also included.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A position on a scale of intensity or amount or quality.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A morphologic qualifier indicating that the grade of a neoplasm cannot be assessed.

Concepts.definition: A morphologic qualifier indicating that the grade of a neoplasm cannot be assessed.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 8/5/2022: created for PMI EC form. SL

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A morphologic qualifier indicating that a cancerous lesion is poorly differentiated.

Concepts.definition: A morphologic qualifier indicating that a cancerous lesion is undifferentiated.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A morphologic qualifier indicating that a cancerous lesion is moderately to poorly differentiated.

Concepts.definition: A morphologic qualifier indicating that a cancerous lesion is poorly differentiated.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A morphologic qualifier indicating that a cancerous lesion is moderately-well differentiated.

Concepts.definition: A morphologic qualifier indicating that a cancerous lesion is moderately differentiated.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A morphologic qualifier indicating that a cancerous lesion is well differentiated.

Concepts.definition: A morphologic qualifier indicating that a cancerous lesion is well differentiated.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A position on a scale of intensity or amount or quality.
